column1: Sapindaceae
column9: Well-drained floodplain forests, riverbanks, rich mesic forests, sand and gravel-bar woodlands, old alluvial fields, and successional forests on disturbed uplands (especially near rivers and streams).

column1: Sapindaceae
column9: Native of Europe, escaped and naturalized in forests, fencerows, and roadsides.

column1: Sapindaceae
column9: Mesic to dry, calcareous upland forests and woodlands; rich floodplain forests, locally common in areas underlain by limestone, dolomite, or calcareous shales

column9: Disturbed forests, old fields, fencerows, road banks, and urban woodlots;

column1: Rosaceae

column9: Well-drained, base-rich nutrient-poor soils

column9: Mesic to dry forests and old fields.

column9: Mesic  upland forest, stram banks

column1: Juglandaceae
column9: Mesic to rather dry upland forests and woodlands, well-drained floodplain forests, and high-elevation deciduous forests

column1: Juglandaceae
column9: Mesic to dry upland forests, but most numerous in moderately to strongly base-rich soils

column9: Mesic to dry upland forests and woodlands; tolerates a wide range of soil conditions

column9: Mesic to dry upland forests and woodlands; tolerant of a range of soil chemistries, occurring widely on base-rich to extremely infertile substrates

column1: Fagaceae
column9: Dry and dry-mesic upland forests and woodlands, most common on dry, rocky ridges with oaks and pines; absent from highly calcareous areas

column1: Cannabaceae

column1: Fabaceae

column9: Mesic to dry upland forests, woodlands, and barrens

column1: Betulaceae
column9: Mesic to dry upland forests, well-drained floodplain forests, rocky woodlands, and old fields.

column1: Rosaceae
column9: Dry, thinly-canopied, shaly or rocky forests, woodlands, and edges.

column1: Ebenaceae
column9: Weedy tree in old fields, fencerows, and roadsides; also scattered in a range of natural habitats, including swamp forests, depression ponds, dune woodlands and scrub, rocky woodlands, and the understory of mesic to dry upland forests.

column9: Mesic to dry forests, woodlands, old fields, fencerows, and roadsides

column9: Seepage swamps, fens, and rocky stream banks on calcareous or mafic substrates

column1: Hamamelidaceae
column9: Mesic to dry mesic upland forest

column1: Aquifoliaceae
column9: Alluvial swamps, seepage swamps, bogs, ponds, and depression swamps

column1: Juglandaceae
column9: Mesic to fairly dry, often rocky upland forests, boulder fields, and stream bankon; base-rich substrates
